subject: Mathematics
note: Content vehicles for Mathematics Year 2. Seeded from v4 teacher feedback (Henderson). Each vehicle is a worked example set following CPA (concrete-pictorial-abstract) progression.

vehicles.name: Place Value with Dienes Blocks
vehicles.description: Understanding place value of two-digit numbers using Dienes blocks (base-10 apparatus). Concrete manipulation of tens and ones leading to pictorial and abstract representations.
difficulty_levels: introductory: partition 2-digit numbers into tens and ones
developing: compare 2-digit numbers using < > =
secure: order a set of numbers and explain reasoning
common_errors: Thinking the digits represent their face value (e.g. 34 = 3 and 4, not 30 and 4)
Confusing tens and ones columns
Writing numbers in reverse order (e.g. writing 41 for fourteen)
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils partition any 2-digit number into tens and ones using Dienes and without? Can they compare pairs of numbers using < > = symbols? Can they order a set of 2-digit numbers and explain their reasoning?
success_criteria: Partition 2-digit numbers into tens and ones
Represent 2-digit numbers using Dienes, place value chart, and numerals
Compare 2-digit numbers using < > = symbols correctly
Order a set of numbers from smallest to largest with explanation

vehicles.name: Addition and Subtraction with Number Lines
vehicles.description: Adding and subtracting 2-digit numbers using number lines and hundred squares. Progresses from concrete counting to efficient mental strategies.
vehicles.cpa_stage: concrete (counting objects) -> pictorial (number line jumps) -> abstract (column method introduction)
difficulty_levels: introductory: add/subtract ones within 20
developing: add/subtract 2-digit and 1-digit numbers
secure: add/subtract two 2-digit numbers
common_errors: Counting from 1 instead of counting on from the larger number
Not bridging through 10 correctly (e.g. 27 + 5)
Subtracting the smaller digit from the larger regardless of position
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils add and subtract 2-digit numbers using a number line, showing jumps? Can they explain commutativity of addition and why subtraction is not commutative? Can they use the inverse to check answers?
success_criteria: Add and subtract 2-digit numbers using number line jumps
Recall addition and subtraction facts to 20 fluently
Explain that addition can be done in any order but subtraction cannot
Use the inverse operation to check answers

vehicles.name: Times Tables: 2, 5 and 10
vehicles.description: Building fluency with 2, 5, and 10 times tables through arrays, repeated addition, and skip counting. Links multiplication to division as grouping and sharing.
vehicles.cpa_stage: concrete (arrays with counters) -> pictorial (array diagrams, bar models) -> abstract (multiplication/division sentences)
difficulty_levels: introductory: count in 2s, 5s, 10s
developing: write multiplication sentences for arrays
secure: use known facts to solve division problems
common_errors: Confusing multiplication and addition (2 x 5 vs 2 + 5)
Not understanding that division is the inverse of multiplication
Thinking division is commutative (10 / 2 = 2 / 10)
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils recall 2, 5, and 10 times tables? Can they write multiplication and division statements using x and / symbols? Can they demonstrate commutativity using arrays? Can they solve simple division by grouping?
success_criteria: Recall 2, 5, and 10 times tables fluently
Write multiplication and division sentences using correct symbols
Show that multiplication is commutative using arrays
Solve division problems by grouping and sharing

vehicles.name: Fractions of Shapes and Quantities
vehicles.description: Introduction to fractions as equal parts of wholes and quantities. Finding 1/2, 1/3, 1/4, 2/4, 3/4 of shapes and sets of objects. First encounter with equivalence (2/4 = 1/2).
vehicles.cpa_stage: concrete (folding paper, sharing objects) -> pictorial (shaded fraction diagrams) -> abstract (fraction notation)
difficulty_levels: introductory: find 1/2 and 1/4 of shapes by folding
developing: find fractions of quantities (1/3 of 12)
secure: recognise equivalence 2/4 = 1/2
common_errors: Not making equal parts (e.g. folding paper into unequal halves)
Thinking 1/3 is bigger than 1/2 because 3 > 2
Not connecting 'fraction of a shape' to 'fraction of a quantity'
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils find 1/2, 1/4, 1/3, 2/4, 3/4 of shapes and quantities? Can they recognise that 2/4 and 1/2 are equivalent? Can they explain why parts must be equal for a fraction to be correct?
success_criteria: Find 1/2, 1/4, 1/3 of shapes by folding or shading
Find fractions of quantities by sharing into equal groups
Recognise that 2/4 = 1/2 using concrete and pictorial models
Explain that fractions require equal parts

vehicles.name: Measuring Length, Mass and Capacity
vehicles.description: Practical measurement using standard units — metres/centimetres, kilograms/grams, litres/millilitres. Choosing appropriate units and reading scales.
vehicles.cpa_stage: concrete (handling measuring equipment) -> pictorial (reading scales, recording in tables) -> abstract (calculating with measures)
difficulty_levels: introductory: estimate and measure using appropriate units
developing: compare and order measurements
secure: solve simple problems involving measures
common_errors: Not starting measurement from zero on a ruler
Confusing units (cm vs m, g vs kg)
Reading scales incorrectly when divisions are not labelled
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils choose an appropriate unit for a given measurement? Can they measure length, mass, capacity, and temperature using standard units? Can they read scales where not all divisions are labelled?
success_criteria: Choose appropriate units for length, mass, capacity, and temperature
Measure accurately using rulers, scales, and measuring jugs
Read scales where not every division is labelled
Compare and order measurements with correct units

vehicles.name: Money: Coins, Notes and Change
vehicles.description: Working with money — recognising coins and notes, making amounts in different ways, calculating change. Real-world application of addition and subtraction.
vehicles.cpa_stage: concrete (real/plastic coins) -> pictorial (coin images, price tags) -> abstract (written calculations with £ and p)
difficulty_levels: introductory: recognise coins and notes, make amounts
developing: find different combinations to make the same amount
secure: calculate change from 50p, £1, £2
common_errors: Confusing the value of coins with their size (5p is bigger than 10p)
Not understanding £1 = 100p
Counting change by subtracting instead of counting up
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils make given amounts using different combinations of coins? Can they use the £ and p symbols correctly? Can they calculate change using counting up or subtraction?
success_criteria: Recognise all UK coins and notes and know their values
Make amounts in at least 2 different ways using coins
Use £ and p symbols correctly (not together: £1.50 or 150p, not £1.50p)
Calculate change from 50p, £1, and £2

vehicles.name: 2-D and 3-D Shapes
vehicles.description: Identifying and describing properties of 2-D and 3-D shapes. Sorting shapes by properties, recognising 2-D shapes on faces of 3-D shapes, and identifying lines of symmetry.
vehicles.cpa_stage: concrete (handling 3-D shapes, cutting 2-D shapes) -> pictorial (sorting diagrams, symmetry drawings) -> abstract (describing properties with vocabulary)
manipulatives: 3-D shape models (cube, cuboid, sphere, cylinder, cone, pyramid)
difficulty_levels: introductory: name and sort common 2-D and 3-D shapes
developing: describe shapes using sides, vertices, faces, edges
secure: identify 2-D shapes on faces of 3-D shapes
common_errors: Confusing sides and vertices
Thinking a square is not a rectangle
Not recognising shapes in different orientations
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils name common 2-D and 3-D shapes? Can they describe shapes using correct mathematical vocabulary (sides, vertices, faces, edges)? Can they identify 2-D shapes on the surface of 3-D shapes? Can they find lines of symmetry?
success_criteria: Name common 2-D shapes (circle, triangle, square, rectangle, pentagon, hexagon)
Name common 3-D shapes (cube, cuboid, sphere, cylinder, cone, pyramid)
Describe shapes using sides, vertices, faces, and edges
Identify 2-D shapes on the surface of 3-D shapes

vehicles.name: Statistics: Pictograms and Tally Charts
vehicles.description: Collecting, presenting, and interpreting data using pictograms, tally charts, block diagrams, and tables. Asking and answering questions about data.
vehicles.cpa_stage: concrete (sorting real objects, collecting data) -> pictorial (pictograms, block diagrams) -> abstract (answering questions from data)
difficulty_levels: introductory: collect data using tally charts
developing: create pictograms and block diagrams
secure: interpret data and answer comparison questions
common_errors: Tally marks not grouped in fives
Pictogram symbols not equal size or spacing
Answering 'how many more' by reading one value instead of finding the difference
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils collect data using a tally chart? Can they construct a pictogram or block diagram from collected data? Can they ask and answer questions including 'how many more/fewer' and 'what is the total'?
success_criteria: Collect and record data using a tally chart
Construct a pictogram with a simple key
Construct a block diagram with labelled axes
Answer comparison questions about data (how many more, total, most/least)
